speaker: BOTH
text_entry: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.

speaker: BOTH
text_entry: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Nay, good my lord, put him to't; let him have his

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: way.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: If your lordship find him not a hilding, hold me no

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: more in your respect.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: On my life, my lord, a bubble.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Do you think I am so far deceived in him?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Believe it, my lord, in mine own direct knowledge,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: without any malice, but to speak of him as my

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: kinsman, he's a most notable coward, an infinite and

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: endless liar, an hourly promise-breaker, the owner

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: of no one good quality worthy your lordship's

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: entertainment.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: It were fit you knew him; lest, reposing too far in

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: his virtue, which he hath not, he might at some

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: great and trusty business in a main danger fail you.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I would I knew in what particular action to try him.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: None better than to let him fetch off his drum,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: which you hear him so confidently undertake to do.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I, with a troop of Florentines, will suddenly

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: surprise him; such I will have, whom I am sure he

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: knows not from the enemy: we will bind and hoodwink

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: him so, that he shall suppose no other but that he

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: is carried into the leaguer of the adversaries, when

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: we bring him to our own tents. Be but your lordship

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: present at his examination: if he do not, for the

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: promise of his life and in the highest compulsion of

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: base fear, offer to betray you and deliver all the

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: intelligence in his power against you, and that with

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: the divine forfeit of his soul upon oath, never

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: trust my judgment in any thing.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: O, for the love of laughter, let him fetch his drum;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: he says he has a stratagem for't: when your

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: lordship sees the bottom of his success in't, and to

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: what metal this counterfeit lump of ore will be

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: melted, if you give him not John Drum's

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: entertainment, your inclining cannot be removed.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Here he comes.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Enter PAROLLES

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: [Aside to BERTRAM]  O, for the love of laughter,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: hinder not the honour of his design: let him fetch

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: off his drum in any hand.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: How now, monsieur! this drum sticks sorely in your

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: disposition.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: A pox on't, let it go; 'tis but a drum.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: 'But a drum'! is't 'but a drum'? A drum so lost!

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: There was excellent command,--to charge in with our

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: horse upon our own wings, and to rend our own soldiers!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That was not to be blamed in the command of the

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: service: it was a disaster of war that Caesar

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: himself could not have prevented, if he had been

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: there to command.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Well, we cannot greatly condemn our success: some

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: dishonour we had in the loss of that drum; but it is

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: not to be recovered.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: It might have been recovered.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: It might; but it is not now.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: It is to be recovered: but that the merit of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: service is seldom attributed to the true and exact

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: performer, I would have that drum or another, or

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: 'hic jacet.'

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Why, if you have a stomach, to't, monsieur: if you

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: think your mystery in stratagem can bring this

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: instrument of honour again into his native quarter,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: be magnanimous in the enterprise and go on; I will

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: grace the attempt for a worthy exploit: if you

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: speed well in it, the duke shall both speak of it.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: and extend to you what further becomes his

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: greatness, even to the utmost syllable of your

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: worthiness.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: By the hand of a soldier, I will undertake it.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: But you must not now slumber in it.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I'll about it this evening: and I will presently

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: pen down my dilemmas, encourage myself in my

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: certainty, put myself into my mortal preparation;

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: and by midnight look to hear further from me.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: May I be bold to acquaint his grace you are gone about it?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I know not what the success will be, my lord; but

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: the attempt I vow.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I know thou'rt valiant; and, to the possibility of

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: thy soldiership, will subscribe for thee. Farewell.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I love not many words.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: No more than a fish loves water. Is not this a

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: strange fellow, my lord, that so confidently seems

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: to undertake this business, which he knows is not to

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: be done; damns himself to do and dares better be

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: damned than to do't?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: You do not know him, my lord, as we do: certain it

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: is that he will steal himself into a man's favour and

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: for a week escape a great deal of discoveries; but

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: when you find him out, you have him ever after.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Why, do you think he will make no deed at all of

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: this that so seriously he does address himself unto?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: None in the world; but return with an invention and

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: clap upon you two or three probable lies: but we

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: have almost embossed him; you shall see his fall

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: to-night; for indeed he is not for your lordship's respect.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: We'll make you some sport with the fox ere we case

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: him. He was first smoked by the old lord Lafeu:

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: when his disguise and he is parted, tell me what a

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: sprat you shall find him; which you shall see this

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: very night.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I must go look my twigs: he shall be caught.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Your brother he shall go along with me.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: As't please your lordship: I'll leave you.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Now will I lead you to the house, and show you

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: The lass I spoke of.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: But you say she's honest.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: That's all the fault: I spoke with her but once

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And found her wondrous cold; but I sent to her,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: By this same coxcomb that we have i' the wind,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Tokens and letters which she did re-send;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And this is all I have done. She's a fair creature:

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Will you go see her?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: With all my heart, my lord.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Exeunt
